Name: The Stevens Mobile
Description: Alexander Calder graduated from Stevens in 1919 with a degree in Mechanical Engineering.  He went on to become a world-renowned sculptor, and his art work is found all over the world.  Calder donated “The Stevens Mobile” to Stevens in 1970 to commemorate the university’s one-hundredth anniversary, and the Library has been its home ever since.

Name: Calder Corner
Location: second floor, near the restrooms and library training room 204
Description: Calder’s stabile sculpture “Hard to Swallow” is found in the “Calder Corner” on the second floor of the Library, along with an exhibit about Calder’s experiences as a student at Stevens.  The exhibit includes Calder’s senior thesis and yearbook, photos, artifacts, and models.

Name: Mary Stuart Stevens Room
Description: The Mary Stuart Stevens Room celebrates the history of the founding family of Stevens Institute of Technology.  The Stevens family has a long history of invention and innovation related to steam boats, railroads, and ferry boats, with roots in America dating back to the late 1600s.

Name: Piano
Description: The Petrof concert grand piano is 9 ft. in length, features several extra keys, and was donated to the Library and dedicated in 1984.  The Library sometimes holds concerts featuring Stevens faculty, students, and special guest artists.

Name: 100 Hoboken Firsts
Description: The “100 Hoboken Firsts” exhibit panels, highlighting fascinating historical facts about Hoboken, were donated to the Library by the Hoboken Historical Museum.

Name: Library History Exhibit
Location: first floor, near Sam’s Place/Drop-In Tutoring Center
Description: This exhibit tells the story of the evolution of the library at Stevens, from 1870 to the present.

Name: Mechanical models
Location: 3rd floor exhibit shelves, near iSTEM and restrooms
Description: The models in this exhibit were used during the late 19th century and early 20th century to demonstrate mechanical engineering principles to Stevens students.

Name: Lieb exhibit
Location: second floor, near the restrooms and library training room 204
Description: John W. Lieb, Class of 1880, attended Stevens during an exciting time for invention.  In the 1880s he worked for the Italian Edison Company while being in the position of Chief Engineer, to set up and install the first central electric station in Europe, which was in Milan, Italy.  Lieb was fascinated by Leonardo da Vinci’s engineering know-how, and this exhibit provides history about Lieb and about the collection of books about Leonardo da Vinci donated to Stevens in the 1930s.
